ui_codex_cont_castles

<paragraph>Early Gothic buildings in Bohemia were inspired by France and the Rhineland. Among the earliest were the monastery in Předklášteří near Tišnov, South Moravia, the chapter house in Osek, North Bohemia, the monastery of St Agnes in Prague and many parish churches and monasteries such as those in Kolin and Kouřim in Central Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>At the turn of the 13th and 14th centuries, Czech architecture diverged from its western counterparts. There was a burgeoning of Cistercian monasteries, e.g. in Zlatá Koruna and Vyšší Brod in South Bohemia, and churches and castles, e.g. Bezděz, North Bohemia. The <accent>High Gothic</accent> period was ushered in during the time of Charles IV and Wenceslas IV, with its rectangular windows and portals, rayonnant traceries and quadripartite, sexpartite, or cross-ribbed vaulting.</paragraph><paragraph>The most significant buildings of that time include Charles University, St Vitus Cathedral, Charles Bridge, Prague Old Town Hall and New Town Hall, stone houses in Prague and the castles of Karlštejn, Kost and Kašperk.</paragraph><paragraph>Records of construction work fellowships first appear during this time: the most famous are those of Master Peter Parler and his family, and Matthias of Arras, who also worked on the reconstruction of Sasau Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph>New castles no longer served just a defensive function, but were also intended to serve as royal residences. They were therefore more spacious and elaborate and had extensive gardens.</paragraph>

<paragraph>波希米亚早期的哥特式建筑的灵感来源于法国和莱茵兰。其中最早的建筑，是南摩拉维亚的提什诺夫（Tišnov）附近的普莱德克拉斯特里（Předklášteří）修道院、北波希米亚的奥赛克的牧师会礼堂、布拉格的圣阿格尼丝修道院，以及很多位于中波希米亚的教区教堂和修道院，例如那些的科林和库日姆（Kouřim）等地的建筑。</paragraph><paragraph>在13世纪至14世纪之交，捷克的建筑风格开始与西方分野。在南波希米亚的泽拉塔克鲁纳（Zlatá Koruna）和维希布罗德（Vyšší Brod）等地区，熙笃会修道院如雨后春笋般崛起，北波希米亚的贝兹德兹（Bezděz）等地区的教堂和城堡亦是如此。查理四世和瓦茨拉夫四世在位期间迎来<accent>哥特盛期</accent>，该时期典型建筑设有矩形的窗户和立面、辐射式的窗花格，以及四分、六分或交叉式的拱顶。</paragraph><paragraph>此时期极具意义的建筑有查理大学、圣维特大教堂、查理大桥、布拉格老市政厅和新市政厅及其他石质建筑、卡尔施泰因城堡（Karlštejn）、科斯特城堡（Kost）、卡斯佩克城堡（Kašperk）等。</paragraph><paragraph>关于建筑工团体的最早记录中，最著名的是彼得·帕勒大师及其家族，还有阿拉斯的马蒂亚斯，后者也曾参与过莎邵修道院的重建工作。</paragraph><paragraph>新城堡不仅被用作防御工事，还是皇室居所，因此被修建得更加宽敞和精美，还配有大型花园。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_cesky_raj

<paragraph>An area, also known as <accent>Bohemian Paradise</accent>, about 90 km north-east of Prague with a great number of natural and cultural monuments. The main landmarks of the region are Kozákov Mountain and <accent>Trosky Castle</accent>, while other important sites include, for example, the Prachov and Klokoči rock formations, the castles Kost, Waldstein and Sychrov, and a number of ponds.</paragraph><paragraph>Its picturesque landscape is mainly underscored by the ubiquitous sandstone rocks, characterised by their steep and rugged reliefs and towers.</paragraph><paragraph>It is an important protected landscape area and a popular destination for climbers. Nowadays the area is crisscrossed with a dense network of tourist trails, making it a haven for nature lovers and enthusiasts of historical landmarks.</paragraph><paragraph>In the medieval period the region was quite bustling, particularly due to the numerous castles, fortresses and fortifications, which are located almost literally on every hilltop.</paragraph>

<paragraph>位于布拉格东北约90公里的地方，有一个被称为<accent>波希米亚伊甸园</accent>的地区，那里拥有大量自然和文化古迹。该地区的主要地标就有科扎科夫山（Kozákov Mountain）和<accent>特罗斯基城堡</accent>，其他著名景点还包括普拉霍夫和克洛科奇岩石群（Prachov and Klokoči rock formations）、科斯特城堡、瓦尔德斯坦城堡、西赫罗夫城堡以及多处池塘。</paragraph><paragraph>那里风景如画，砂岩随处可见，以其崎岖、峻峭、塔状林立为特色。</paragraph><paragraph>这里是一处重要的景观保护区，也吸引着大批攀岩爱好者。如今，这处自然和古迹爱好者的天堂，纵横交织着密集的游览线路。</paragraph><paragraph>中世纪时期，这片地区格外繁华，尤其是数不胜数的城堡、堡垒以及防御工事，几乎每座山丘上都能看到它们耸立的身影。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_fashion

<paragraph>Clothing for villagers and common folk had to be comfortable, durable and practical. It consisted of a simple shirt and a tunic. Men also wore <italic>braies</italic> (knee-length linen drawers). In winter they wore hooded cloaks, furs and hats. All typically in natural colours without embellishments. The exception was <accent>festive attire</accent> for special occasions and religious holidays.</paragraph><paragraph>In the city, clothing reflected status, wealth, but also affiliation to a particular group, such as craftsmen, soldiers or apprentices. Belts, bags, gloves, hats and other headgear were used as accessories.</paragraph><heading>Hairstyles</heading><paragraph><accent>Unwed young women</accent> had long hair, which they wore down or in braids. Women in towns adorned their hair with ribbons, pearls, wreaths and vines. Older <accent>married women</accent> wore pearled nets on their heads, white or coloured veils or hats. Fashionable <accent>men</accent> had long, coiffured hair, they liked to shave their chins and wear various headwear.</paragraph><heading>Jewellery</heading><paragraph>Jewellery was fashioned from gems, wood, leather and metals. The most common types of jewellery were <accent>earrings</accent>, various types of crosses and, in the High Middle Ages, <accent>rings</accent>, which were both representative and symbolic. Floral and animal themes as well as figural motifs inspired by religious themes predominated in decoration.</paragraph><heading>Footwear</heading><paragraph>Shoes were made of leather, but also of grass, straw, bast, wood, cloth or felt. In the countryside, people often went barefoot in summertime. <accent>Soles</accent> (left and right) on shoes first appeared in the mid 14th century while heels were added in the 15th century.The most common type of footwear consisted of sandals and slippers made of wood or cork. Stitched shoes were called either <italic>škrpály</italic> (low shoes) or <italic>škorně</italic> (above the ankle).</paragraph>

<paragraph>对村民和其他平民来说，服装最首要的是舒适、结实和实用，通常多是些简单的衬衫和短袍。男人也会穿着及膝的<italic>亚麻裤</italic>，冬天时还会穿兜帽斗篷、皮外套和帽子。大部分服装都是自然朴素的颜色，没有装饰。为了宗教假日和特殊庆祝场合准备的<accent>节庆服装</accent>则是例外。</paragraph><paragraph>在镇上，服装能够反映穿着者的社会地位、财富状况，当然还反映了特有的身份，例如工匠、士兵或学徒。配饰包含腰带、袋子、手套、帽子和其他头罩等。</paragraph><heading>发型</heading><paragraph><accent>未婚女子</accent>留披肩长发或是编成辫子。镇上的女人会用丝带、珍珠、花环和藤蔓装饰头发。年长的<accent>已婚女子</accent>会在头上戴珍珠网，白色或彩色的面纱，或者帽子。时髦的<accent>男人</accent>会留长发并做成发型，他们还会剃须，穿戴各式各样的头饰。</paragraph><heading>珠宝</heading><paragraph>珠宝首饰由宝石、木头、皮革和金属制成。最常见的首饰为<accent>耳环</accent>、各种各样的十字架，以及在中世纪兴盛时期流行的<accent>戒指</accent>，当时的戒指既可以代表身份，又具有象征意义。首饰上的装饰图案主要是花朵和动物，以及受宗教主题启发的人物形象。</paragraph><heading>鞋子</heading><paragraph>当时的鞋子由皮革制成，也有些用青草、稻草、树皮、木头、布或者毛毡制成。每到夏天，乡下人经常光脚出行。区分左右脚的<accent>鞋底</accent>首次出现于14世纪中期，而鞋跟则出现于15世纪时。最常见的鞋子有木质或软木的凉鞋和拖鞋。缝制的鞋子包括<italic>škrpály</italic>（低帮）和<italic>škorně</italic>（高帮）两种。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_gunpowder

<paragraph>Black powder is the oldest known explosive, discovered around the 9th century in China. Initially, it was used in medicine and widely experimented with by alchemists. However, when it failed to yield the anticipated elixir of immortality, its powerful explosive properties began to be used for ammunition production. It likely arrived in Europe as early as the 13th century, although some experts believe that Europeans discovered black powder independently of China.</paragraph><paragraph>The European inventor of gunpowder is typically attributed to either the German alchemist Berthold "The Black" Schwarz, or, according to other sources, the German friar Albertus Magnus, who was familiar with the recipe for gunpowder as early as 1275. Another mention can be found in the work of the alchemist Marcus Graecus, who included a black powder recipe in his writings around 1300. However, at this time, gunpowder was not yet commonly used in combat.</paragraph><paragraph>Originally, a fine particle mixture known as “meal powder,” produced by grinding the individual components, was used for shooting. Later, methods were developed to produce larger grains, which significantly improved the consistency of ballistic properties and accuracy in shooting.</paragraph>

<paragraph>黑火药是目前已知最古老的炸药，大约在9世纪由中国人发明。黑火药最初被用于医疗领域，且广泛地用于炼丹师的实验当中。显然，黑火药并没能如同预期般地成为长生不老药，但那之后人们利用它的爆炸特性将其用于弹药生产中。黑火药可能早在13世纪便已传入欧洲，也有一些专家声称欧洲人是独立发现黑火药的。</paragraph><paragraph>欧洲火药的发明者通常被认为是德国炼金术士贝索德·施瓦茨。也有一些其他的说法，比如德国修士阿尔伯特·麦格努斯，据说他早在1275年就掌握了火药配方。也有关于炼金术师马库斯·格拉厄库斯的记载，他在大约1300年的著作之中收录了一份黑火药的配方。不过，在那段时间，火药还并未广泛用于战争之中。</paragraph><paragraph>最初人们使用的火药是一种研磨而成的，称为“粉末火药”的细颗粒混合物，通常用于射击。之后人们研发出了生产较大颗粒火药的方法，大大提高了其弹道性能、射击精度和稳定性。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_hunter

<paragraph>Hunting in the Middle Ages was not only a pastime but also brought significant economic profit to the king and the nobility who owned the forests. The noble <accent>hunters</accent> also acted as forest managers, taking care of the game as well as maintaining and protecting the forest.</paragraph> <paragraph>It was forbidden to hunt deer, fallow deer, roebucks, wild boars, and indeed any other game in the forests. Violating this prohibition was punishable by a high fine, or in the case of repeated offenses, even physical punishment. The same applied to unauthorized wood gathering and logging.</paragraph> <paragraph>Many <accent>poachers</accent> came from poorer social classes and had little to lose, so physical confrontations with the gamekeepers who caught them in the act were not uncommon.</paragraph>

<paragraph>在中世纪，巡猎和狩猎不仅仅是为了娱乐，他们还是国王和拥有森林的贵族的巨大利润来源。所以巡猎者和猎人也要承担林务工作。除了要负责照看野生动物外，他们还负责森林及其保护的管理。</paragraph><paragraph>在森林中，禁止狩猎鹿、狍子、野猪或其他野生动物，违反此规定是重罪，在连续违反的情况下，甚至会处以死刑。擅自砍伐和收集木材同样如此。</paragraph><paragraph>然而，偷猎者大多是穷人，他们无路可退，因此，对偷猎者的抓捕最后经常会演变成流血冲突。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_jan_sokol<years>cca. 1355 – 28 September 1410</years><paragraph>Jan Sokol of Lamberg was a military leader, provincial governor, son of Jaroslav of Kninice, and a friend of Radzig Kobyla.</paragraph><paragraph>He actively participated in the internal disputes of the Luxembourg dynasty, siding with Wenceslas IV. For his loyalty, the king rewarded him with the village of Horky and the castle of Skalitz near Kostelec in Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1404, Jan fought against Sigismund of Luxembourg at Znojmo. As a member of Wenceslas's retinue, he met Jan Zizka in 1409 and went into battle against the Rosenbergs with him. He fought in the Battle of Grunwald, where he sided with the Polish-Lithuanian coalition. After the battle, he was likely poisoned at a feast at the court of Polish King Władysław Jagiełło.</paragraph><years>约1355年 – 1410年9月28日</years><paragraph>兰伯格的约翰·索科尔，是金尼斯的雅罗斯洛夫之子， 拉德季·科比拉之友，也是摩拉维亚的督军。</paragraph><paragraph>他是卢森堡王朝内乱中的关键人物，也是支持瓦茨拉夫的一员。得救后的国王为表彰其忠诚，当即将波希米亚境内的霍基村，以及科思泰莱茨附近的斯卡利茨城堡赏给了索科尔。</paragraph><paragraph>1404年，扬与卢森堡的西格斯蒙德在兹诺伊莫交战。作为瓦茨拉夫的盟友，他于1409年联合扬·杰式卡抗击罗森堡。他加入波兰与立陶宛联军，参加了格伦瓦尔德战役。战役之后，波兰国王弗拉迪斯拉夫·雅盖隆，疑似在一场宴会上对约翰下了毒。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_loupeze<paragraph>Thievery and banditry were 'dishonourable professions', whose practitioners were often known in the wider area - that is, if they could evade justice long enough.</paragraph><paragraph>Petty theft most often happened in villages, town markets or taverns. In short, where thieves could hide in the crowd. But people were in greater danger in the open countryside, outside their settlements, or in remote villages, where victims could rarely call for help. Bandits therefore often threatened merchants and travellers on the road, especially around the richer towns, where they flocked to do business.</paragraph><paragraph>Some <accent>bands of robbers</accent> were organised and operated under the auspices of rebelious nobles who profited from their actions. At times they even resorted to raiding entire villages or towns. They would then sell off their loot in markets or taverns.</paragraph><paragraph>The execution books give us evidence of the fate of those, who became involved with bandits. In one of them, we read about Jan Zizka, that: <italic>'He steals herrings and killed a hired hand of the Rosenberg's.'</italic></paragraph><paragraph>偷盗是一种“不光彩”的职业，精通此道的人也会臭名远扬——如果他们还未落入法网的话。</paragraph><paragraph>偷盗常发生在村中、市场或是酒馆内，简单地说，人群中可能随时藏着小偷。但是，在旷野荒山或是偏远村庄这种人烟罕至的地方，人们可能所面临的境况更为险恶。这种地方的强盗们常常会胁迫路过的商人或旅客，在繁华且有活跃市场的城镇周边这种现象尤为突出。</paragraph><paragraph>一些<accent>强盗团伙</accent>接受着反叛贵族们的资助，并在他们的组织与运作下，通过恶行为他们谋利。有时候，他们还会洗劫整座村庄或城镇，事后再到市场或酒馆内进行销赃。</paragraph><paragraph>与处决有关的记录向我们揭露了那些与强盗有染之人的命运，在其中，我们还读到了与扬·杰式卡有关的信息：<italic>“他偷走鲱鱼，并杀死了罗森堡的一位雇工。”</italic></paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_musicians<paragraph>Theatre as we know it today was not widespread in the Middle Ages and was used more for church purposes (passion plays). Art in the high court, on the other hand, was not comprehensible to commoners, so the profession of folk entertainer was established for a variety of purposes.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Minstrels</accent> were seen at fairs and markets; they made the rounds of taverns and were even hired by wealthy merchants or nobles. The minstrel’s repertoire could include singing, playing musical instruments, juggling, staging scenes or narrating humorous stories.</paragraph><paragraph>The themes of their work were mostly light and cheerful, but often included satire or criticism of political conditions, whether coming from the minstrels themselves, or paid for by an employer and tailored to their intentions. Most of the minstrels had no employer, they belonged to the margins of society and had to get by from day to day through alms.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Musicians</accent> enjoyed a bit more respect and besides entertainment, their music could also be used during religious services. Popular medieval instruments included flutes, trumpets, shawms, as well as lutes, harps and drums. Their performances were mostly improvised, but early musical notations also began to appear at this time.</paragraph><paragraph>There were both, professional musicians employed at court or churches and travelling musicians playing in markets and at celebrations. This craft was predominantly pursued by men.</paragraph><paragraph>我们今天所知道的剧院在中世纪其实并不普遍，主要用于教会用途（如受难剧）。另一方面，高贵的宫廷艺术也不为普通人所喜爱，因此为了各种目的，民间艺人的职业得以确立。</paragraph><paragraph><accent>吟游诗人</accent>开始出现在集市和市场上；他们在酒馆里巡回演出，甚至被富商或贵族雇佣。吟游诗人的节目可能包括唱歌、演奏乐器、杂耍、舞台剧或讲述幽默故事。</paragraph><paragraph>他们作品的主题大多是轻松愉快的内容，但也经常是对政治的讽刺或批评，这些政见可能来自吟游诗人自己，也可能是为雇主量身定制的。不过大多数吟游诗人都没有雇主，他们属于社会边缘群体，靠打赏度日。</paragraph><paragraph><accent>音乐家</accent>则享有更多的尊重，除了娱乐，他们的音乐还可以用于宗教仪式中。中世纪最流行的乐器是长笛、小号、肖姆笛、鲁特琴、竖琴和鼓。他们的音乐作品大多是即兴创作的，不过最早的乐谱也出自这一时期。</paragraph><paragraph>宫廷或教会会雇佣职业的音乐家，而未受雇佣的流浪音乐家则会在市场和庆典上演奏，绝大多数的音乐家都是男性。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_opatovice<paragraph>As the name suggests, the village probably owes its foundation to the abbots (opati) of the nearby Sedletz Monastery, who from the 13th century tried to colonise this inhospitable and sparsely populated region. The first written mention of the village dates back to the latter half of the 14th century, when it belonged to the Kuttenberg burgher Jan Glenc.</paragraph><paragraph>The farmstead of Opatowitz was founded sometime during the 14th century by the monastery, which subsequently supported it until it was sold to another wealthy Kuttenberg burgher, Wenceslas Bartosch (Václav Bartoš), in 1379.</paragraph><paragraph>正如其名所示，这座村庄的建立或许得归功于附近塞德莱茨修道院的院长们（opati），自13世纪以来，他们曾试图在这荒无人烟的不毛之地上殖民。该村庄首次于书中有所提及可追溯至14世纪下半叶，当时它属于名为扬·格伦茨的库滕堡市民。</paragraph><paragraph>14世纪期间，修道院还建造了奥帕托维茨农庄，并对其经营发展施以支持，一直到农庄于1379年专卖给了一位富有的库滕堡市民，此人名叫瓦茨拉夫·巴托什（Václav Bartoš）。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_polsko<paragraph>In Poland at the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, similar to the Czech lands, wars over governance, territory, and faith were occurring. The country's prosperity and its cultural and economic growth were particularly hampered by the relentless attacks of the Teutonic Knights from the so-called Crusader states on northern Polish territories, justified by the need for Christianization and the suppression of the still dominant paganism in the Baltic region.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, Poland was not unified for long, because after the death of Casimir III the Great, the Piast dynasty, which had long unified and ruled the country, ended in the male line. The crown was taken by Casimir's cousin, Ludwig I of Anjou, the King of Hungary, but he struggled to gain the obedience of the Polish nobility, and his rule and ability to unite a larger coalition against the Crusader invasion were thus very limited.</paragraph><paragraph>The most suitable solution eventually was the marriage of Ludwig's daughter Hedwig to Jagell, the Grand Duke of Lithuania. He took the name Vladislav, was accepted as the King of Poland, and, along with the rest of Lithuania, was baptized. This created the Polish-Lithuanian coalition, which significantly weakened the Teutonic Order.</paragraph><paragraph>However, the Crusaders did not want to give up so easily, and the war continued for many more years. A turning point in this conflict was the Battle of Grunwald in 1410, in which the Teutonic forces were decisively defeated by the Polish-Lithuanian army. ui_codex_oldrich_vavak<paragraph>Twice during his life, he was appointed Royal Mint Master, and after the outbreak of the Hussite uprising, he was one of the few representatives of the higher Czech nobility to join the rebels.</paragraph><paragraph>We know nothing about his life before the outbreak of the uprising, except that in the years 1402-1403 (or 1404), during King Wenceslas's absence from Bohemia, he held the office of Mint Master.</paragraph><paragraph>His later life is documented, during which he supported Jan Hus and complained to King Sigismund about his burning. He marched into battle alongside Jan Zizka, and in 1421, he became the Mint Master of Kuttenberg for the second time.</paragraph><paragraph>他一生两次被任命为皇家铸币官，在胡斯起义爆发后，他是少数几个加入叛乱者的捷克高级贵族。</paragraph><paragraph>我们对他在起义爆发前的经历知之甚少，只知道在1402年至1403年（或1404年）期间，在瓦茨拉夫国王未掌管波希米亚之时，他担任过铸币官。</paragraph><paragraph>但他的晚年经历却有详细记载。当时的他支持扬·胡斯，并向国王西格斯蒙德揭露了扬·胡斯被烧死一事。他曾发起对《布拉格四项条款》（the Four Articles of Prague）的商讨（该条款决定了起义的方向和要求），并在查斯劳大会（the Congress of Tschaslau）上被选为贵族代表，加入了临时政府。他曾与扬·杰式卡并肩作战，并于1421年在库滕堡第二次担任铸币官。</paragraph>
ui_codex_suchy_cert<paragraph>Originally named Hynek Jevišovský of Kunstadt, he was a fierce and fearless soldier who became famous as a robber knight during the Moravian Margraviate Wars, in which he repeatedly raided Austria in 1401 and 1402, continuing even after the first capture of the Bohemian king in Vienna.</paragraph><paragraph>Only after the escape of King Wenceslas IV did the Austrian Duke Albrecht lose patience and so in 1404 he marched on Znojmo with 12,000 soldiers supported by another 12,000 soldiers of Sigismund of Luxembourg. However, the Dry Devil knew about the campaign. When the enemy troops stood in front of the town, it was already fortified and with substantial help from his friend Jan Sokol of Lamberg he repelled the attack. It should be noted that a dysentery epidemic, which had spread among the enemy to such an extent that both enemy nobles were infected, also contributed greatly to this. Albrecht IV of Austria even died of the disease.</paragraph><paragraph>And so the Dry Devil continued to pillage and plunder.Eventually, however, even Wenceslas IV ran out of patience and had Hynek imprisoned in 1407. He was soon released, but did not enjoy his freedom very long, for he died in 1408.</paragraph><paragraph>此人原名海尼克·耶维绍夫斯基·库斯塔特（Hynek Jevišovský of Kunstadt），他是一位勇猛无畏的战士，在摩拉维亚的边疆侯爵战争期间变成了一个臭名昭著的强盗骑士，并于1401与1402年频繁袭击奥地利，在波希米亚国王受囚禁于维也纳期间，他仍未罢休。</paragraph><paragraph>瓦茨拉夫四世国王逃脱后，奥地利公爵阿尔布雷希特才失去了耐心。1404年，他带领12000名战士，协同卢森堡的西格斯蒙德手下的12000兵力进军兹诺伊莫。但是，“酒鬼”提前得知了此消息。当敌军兵临城下，此时的城镇早已严加设防，且在盟友兰贝格的扬·索科尔的帮助下击退袭击。但值得注意的是，这场胜利很大程度上也得归功于在敌军阵营中传播蔓延的疾病痢疾，敌方贵族同样受到感染，奥德利的阿尔布雷希特四世还因此命丧黄泉。</paragraph><paragraph>于是，“酒鬼”继续干着劫掠的勾当。但是最后，就连瓦茨拉夫四世都失去了耐心，并于1407年将海尼克囚禁了起来。而后他很快又得到了释放，只是还未能享受足够的自由便于1408年离世。</paragraph>

ui_helpoverlay_dice0_s0900You start the game by rolling all six dice. Select the scoring dice you want keep (put them to the side and gain points for them at the end of your turn), then roll the rest again. You can keep rolling until you run out of dice. <br/> <br/>However, if you don't roll a single scoring die, you lose all points gained this turn.<br/> <br/>The art of dice is to finish your turn and score your points before you run the risk of not rolling a single scoring die. <br/> <br/>The first player to reach the score goal is the victor. You can see all point information for the current game in the bottom left corner.游戏开始时，你将掷骰全部六颗骰子。然后标记你想要的获分骰子，接着可再次掷骰剩余的骰子。只要你还有至少一颗骰子留存在对局内，你就可以继续掷骰。<br/> <br/>然而，如果你在某次掷骰中没有掷出任何获分骰子，那么你将失去那一轮得到的所有分数，并且轮到你的对手进行他的回合。<br/> <br/>掷骰的诀窍在于在合适的时间结束你的回合，以免失去已经获得的分数。<br/> <br/>最先获得规定分数的玩家获胜。你可以在左下角查看所有与对局有关的信息。
